newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RUGBY UNION-SMITH CHANGES HIS MIND ON KNOX.
newsitem.headline: RUGBY UNION-SMITH CHANGES HIS MIND ON KNOX.

text.p: Australia on Monday recalled veteran fly-half David Knox to their squad for this weekend's Tri-Nations rugby union test against South Africa in a remarkable change of heart by coach Greg Smith.
Knox will interrupt a playing stint with South African province Natal to join a 22-man Wallaby squad for Saturday's Brisbane test after Tim Horan was ruled out with a broken hand.

Australia are to make at least two other changes from the side beaten 33-18 by New Zealand in a Tri-Nations test on Saturday after dropping back rower Michael Brial and losing full-back Matt Burke to injury.
Smith has repeatedly cited Knox's lack of defensive strength as the reason behind his decision to ignore the ACT Brumbies' goal-kicker this season.
But in a sudden turnaround on Monday, Smith said in a statement: "With the injury to Tim Horan's hand, Knox is an automatic choice for the Wallaby fly-half position."
Yet in comments reported in The Australian newspaper earlier in the day, Smith said selecting Knox would prove too great a risk because of his supposed defensive weakness.
"I don't think we can afford to (select Knox). He's a non-tackler," Smith was quoted as saying.

The 33-year-old goal-kicker last played for Australia on the tour to Britain late last year but had failed to earn a place in any of Smith's squads for tests against England, France and New Zealand so far this season.
Brial's demotion appeared inevitable from the moment Smith singled out the back rower for blame after the All Blacks demolished the Wallabies in Melbourne to lift the Bledisloe Cup.
Veteran Troy Coker was expected to come into the side at number eight, with Stephen Larkham replacing Burke at full-back.
In justifying his previous selection decisions, Smith has repeatedly argued that Knox's acknowledged attacking talent did not compensate for his defensive frailty.
Smith, under intense pressure to keep his job next season, looked instead to Horan's tackling strength and ability to run directly at defenders.
But the selection policy caused widespread misgivings, with critics questioning Horan's suitability by citing concerns about the slow speed of his passing and the lack of a kicking game.
Knox, 33, a proven goal-kicker, enjoyed an outstanding season for ACT Brumbies in the Super 12 competition, helping the province to a losing final against Auckland in May.
Both South Africa and Australia lost to New Zealand in their opening Tri-Nations matches.
Forwards - Richard Harry, Michael Foley, Marco Caputo, Andrew Heath, Andrew Blades, Garrick Morgan, John Eales (captain), Matt Cockbain, Brett Robinson, David Wilson, Daniel Manu, Troy Coker.
Backs - George Gregan, Sam Payne, David Knox, Elton Flatley, James Holbeck, Jason Little, Joe Roff, Ben Tune, Mitch Hardy, Stephen Larkham.
